items.title: Hundreds of thousands left without power as winter storm heads through eastern US | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
A powerful winter storm is pummeling parts of the eastern US after sweeping through the Midwest. Some areas have seen their heaviest snowfall in decades. The storm has been blamed for least three deaths. Hundreds of thousands are without power.

Chapters:
0:00 US winter snow storm
1:43 Matthew Cappucci, Meteorologist

items.title: Why Musk's whims could stop him supporting Germany's far-right AfD party | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
We begin with the tech billionaire who's fast becoming a political force. Since taking charge of X -- formerly known as Twitter -- Elon Musk has used the social media platform as a platform for his own political views. And, after spending millions of dollars helping to secure Donald Trump’s return to the White House, he's now wading into European politics -- expressing support for far-right and anti-establishment parties across Europe, including here in Germany. In December, he tweeted his support for the far-right, Alternative for Germany party -- or AfD. With a general election in February, the AfD is polling second - and parts of the party are being monitored by German domestic security services as "possible threats to democracy". 

He's also attacked Germany's leaders, saying that Chancellor Olaf Scholz, "should resign immediately," and calling him an "incompetent fool". And of German president, Frank-Walter Steinmeier, he said, "Steinmeier is an anti-democratic tyrant! Shame on him".  Berlin has accused Elon Musk of election interference. 

For more news go to: http://www.dw.com/en/

items.title: Why Volkswagen's unique history could cause its downfall | Business Beyond
items.author: DW News
items.content:
Volkswagen, Europe’s biggest car maker, is in crisis. A shrinking European market, more competition in China and slow electric vehicle uptake mean VW must cut costs. But Volkswagen functions differently from any other car maker in the world. It’s not just VW’s management that has the final say, but also its workers. In this episode of Business Beyond, we look at Volkswagen’s unique governance structure and what it means for the car maker’s ability to react to challenges.  

For more from the experts we spoke to: 
Clemens Fuest, ifo Institute https://commission.europa.eu/persons/clemens-fuest_en 
Carsten Brzeski, ING Germany https://think.ing.com/author/carsten-brzeski/ 
Martin Murphy, Handelsblatt https://www.handelsblatt.com/autoren/martin-murphy/1986538.html 
Matthias Schmidt, European Automotive Market Intelligence https://www.schmidtmatthias.de/ 
Jens Dralle, Auto Motor und Sport https://www.auto-motor-und-sport.de/autor/jens-dralle/ 
 
#Businessbeyond #volkswagen  #electricvehicles 

Chapters:
00:00 Intro
02:09 Volkswagen’s unique structure
04:50 How did we get here?
08:42 Volkswagen’s cost problem
11:56 Volkswagen’s path forward?

items.author: DW News
items.content:

items.title: Austria's far-right Freedom Party leader Herbert Kickl is asked to form a government | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
The far-right Freedom Party has been given a mandate to lead the Austria, after the collapse of coalition talks between centrists.  President Alexander Van der Bellen has tasked the Freedom Party's leader Herbert Kickl with forming a new government. If he's successful, Austria would have the country's first government led by the far-right since World War II.

00:00 Protests as far-right Freedom Party is tasked with forming a new government in Austria.
02:09 Journalist Steve Chaid reports on how coalition talks could progress.  

#Kickl  #Austria #fpö

items.title: Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau to step down, cites party in-fighting | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has announced that he will resign as Liberal Party leader, bowing to growing pressure from within his own party.  Mr Trudeau said party in-fighting meant it was clear he wasn't the best choice to lead them into general elections this year.

Correction: Canada's parliament will be suspended until March 24 this year, not March 26, as our correspondent said in this interview.

00:00 Canadian PM Justin Trudeau resigns
00:33 Trudeau cites party in-fighting for decision to step down
01:00  DW correspondent Janelle Dumalaon in Washington D.C. reports on who could replace Trudeau as Canada plans elections later this year

items.title: Why is Germany defunding NGOs critical of the Israeli government? | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
An investigation by DW found that the German government has quietly cut funding for several human rights organizations that have often been critical of Israel's actions in the war in Gaza. Since the Hamas terror-attack on Israel on October 7th, 2023 politicians in Germany have repeatedly emphasized that Israel's security is part of Germany's "Staatsräson" -  or "reason of state." DW’s investigative team has more.

00:00  The German government cuts funding for several human rights organizations.

00:30  Report on funding cuts for Israeli NGOs New Profile and  Zochrot 

05:12  DW Investigative reporter Naomi Conrad talks about how unusual this step is.

For more news go to: http://www.dw.com/en/

items.title: Russia says it has taken key Ukraine stronghold Kurakhove | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
Russia says its troops have taken the strategic stronghold of Kurakhove in Ukraine's Donetsk region. Kurakhove, a logistics hub, has held out for months. If Moscow has indeed taken the town, it would enable its forces to step up the pace of their advance in Donetsk. Images showing troops raising a Russian flag have been geolocated by Reuters news agency to Kurakhove. Meanwhile Russia is dealing with a new Ukrainian offensive inside the Kursk region of western Russia. 

00:00 Russia says it has key Ukraine stronghold
00:49 DW speaks with  Fabrice Pothier, Consulting Senior Fellow for Defence Policy and Strategy at Rasmussen Global

items.title: What it means for democracy if Trump pardons January 6 rioters | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
Two weeks before leaving office, US President Joe Biden has spoken to new Democratic members of Congress about the importance of enabling the peaceful transfer of power. Biden was speaking Sunday, a day ahead of the fourth anniversary of the storming of the US Capitol building, when then-President Donald Trump's supporters tried to stop the certification of the 2020 election.
As Trump prepares to return to the White House, he has promised to pardon many of the people charged with criminal offenses that day. What could that mean for the defendants, and for democracy?

00:00 Will Trump pardon January 6 rioters?
03:24 DW speaks with Cathryn Clüver Ashbrook, senior adviser at the Bertelsmann foundation and expert on US politics

items.title: Why Ukraine is launching its new Kursk offensive right now | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
The office of President Volodymyr Zelensky says Ukrainian forces have launched a new offensive in Russia's Kursk region. 

Ukrainian troops have occupied Russian soil since August, when they first advanced into the Kursk area, and have resisted efforts to expel them. Russian media, citing the country's defense ministry, say their troops have so far repelled these latest Ukrainian advances. 

00:00 New Ukrainian offensive in Russia's Kursk region
00:28 Marina Miron, military analyst at King’s College London

items.title: Israel-Hamas war: 34 hostages to be exchanged in a possible ceasefire? | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
There is conflicting information as to whether the Palestinian militant group Hamas has approved a list of hostages to be released in Gaza. Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu says Hamas has not provided a list of names. But, a Hamas official earlier told Reuters news agency that the group had approved a list of 34 hostages presented by Israel to be exchanged in a possible ceasefire. Also earlier Israel said indirect negotiations had resumed in Qatar for a ceasefire and hostage release deal.

Despite the talks, Israel has stepped up airstrikes in Gaza, killing dozens of people.

00:00 Hostage and ceasefire deal?
02:09 Journalist Karim El-Gawhary

For more news go to: http://www.dw.com/en/

items.title: What makes far-right parties so appealing to voters? | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
Austrias President Alexander van der Bellen says he will hold talks with the leader of the far-right Freedom Party on Monday, to seek a way out of the country's political stalemate. 
The president made the announcement after meeting Chancellor Karl Nehammer - who is resigning following the breakdown of coalition talks between his conservatives and the Social Democrats. Together, the two parties had sought to prevent the far-right Freedom Party - which won the most votes in September's election - from forming a government. 
The breakdown of the talks could pave the way for far-right FPÖ leader Herbert Kickl to come to power, with the conservatives serving as junior partners - despite previous unwillingness to work with the far-right. 

Chapters
00:00 Coalition talks collapse in Austria, chancellor resigns
00:48 Alexander van der Bellen, Austrian President
01:35 Steve Chaid, Journalist
05:16 Natascha Strobl, Political scientist
